tn.ref: Haman
tn.text: Translate this man's name as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:est:03:01|3:1]].

tn.ref: On this second day
tn.text: "on this second day of feasting"

tn.ref: while they were serving wine
tn.text: "while the servants were pouring the wine and giving it to them" or "while the wine was being served"

tn.ref: What is your petition
tn.text: The abstract noun "petition" can be expressed with the verb "ask for" or "want." AT: "What do you ask for" or "What do you want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: It will be granted to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will give you what you ask for" or "I will do for you what you ask" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Up to half of the kingdom, and it will be granted
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If you ask for up to half of my kingdom, I will give it to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: If I have found favor in your eyes, king
tn.text: "Find favor" is an idiom that means be approved of or that he is pleased with her. "In your eyes" is a metaphor representing his evaluation. AT: "if you evaluate me and approve" or "if you are pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: let my life be given to me
tn.text: Giving life represents rescuing a person from being killed. AT: "save me life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: this is my petition
tn.text: The abstract noun "petition" can be expressed with the verb "ask for." AT: "this is what I ask for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: For we have been sold
tn.text: Being sold represents being betrayed. This can be stated in active form. AT: "For someone has betrayed us" or "For someone has put us in danger of our enemies" (See: [:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: to be destroyed, killed, and annihilated
tn.text: Here all three words have the same meaning and are used for emphasis. This can be stated in active form. AT: "for our enemies to destroy, kill, and annihilate us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Where is the one who has filled his heart to do such a thing
tn.text: To fill one's heart to do something is an idiom meaning to dare to do something. AT: "Where is the one who had dared to so such a thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: terrified
tn.text: "extremely afraid"

tn.ref: The king got up in a rage
tn.text: Being in a rage is an idiom for being extremely angry. AT: "The king was extremely angry and got up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: to beg for his life from Queen Esther
tn.text: "to beg Queen Esther to save his life"

tn.ref: He saw that disaster was being decided
tn.text: Here seeing represents realizing or understanding. AT: "He realized that disaster was being decided" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: disaster was being decided against him by the king
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. The abstract noun "disaster" can be expressed with the more concrete verbs "destroy" or "kill." AT: "the king was deciding to cause a disaster against him" or "the king was deciding to destroy him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: where the wine had been served
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "where servants had served the wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: couch
tn.text: a long piece of furniture where a person can sit or lie down

tn.ref: Will he assault the queen in my presence in my own house?
tn.text: The king uses this question to show his shock and anger at what Haman was doing. AT: "He even dares to attack the queen in my presence and in my own house!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: assault the queen
tn.text: "attack the queen." This phrase is a polite way to refer to rape. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: As soon as this sentence came out of the king's mouth
tn.text: Speech coming out of the mouth represents speaking. AT: "As soon as the king said this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the servants covered Haman's face
tn.text: Apparently they did this because they understood that the king wanted Haman to be killed. AT: "the servants covered Haman's face as a sign that he would be killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Harbona
tn.text: This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: a gallows fifty cubits tall
tn.text: You may convert "fifty cubits" to a modern measure. Translate this as you did a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:est:05:14|5:14]]. AT: "twenty-three meters high" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]])

tn.ref: Then the king's rage died down
tn.text: The king's rage is a spoken of as if it were a large fire that became smaller. AT: "Then the king's rage lessened" or "Then the king was not so angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
